body_html:
@wt-huang Thanks for the help and sorry for the late reply as I missed the email notification.

In the implementation,

  • If OutOfRange is encountered and no data is available (record.empty()), then the implementation will move to the next file as we consider this is the end of file as expected.
  • If OutOfRange is encountered and there are partial data (!record.empty()), then the implementation will consider this case as errors::DataLoss:
    https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/21861/files#diff-543e4ff75a82c917f5d7ee97efb31112R536

I think the scenarios may have been covered in the implementation.
body_text:
@wt-huang Thanks for the help and sorry for the late reply as I missed the email notification.
In the implementation,

If OutOfRange is encountered and no data is available (record.empty()), then the implementation will move to the next file as we consider this is the end of file as expected.
If OutOfRange is encountered and there are partial data (!record.empty()), then the implementation will consider this case as errors::DataLoss:
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/21861/files#diff-543e4ff75a82c917f5d7ee97efb31112R536

I think the scenarios may have been covered in the implementation.
body:
@wt-huang Thanks for the help and sorry for the late reply as I missed the email notification.

In the implementation,
- If `OutOfRange` is encountered and no data is available (`record.empty()`), then the implementation will move to the next file as we consider this is the end of file as expected.
- If `OutOfRange` is encountered and there are partial data (`!record.empty()`), then the implementation will consider this case as `errors::DataLoss`:
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/21861/files#diff-543e4ff75a82c917f5d7ee97efb31112R536

I think the scenarios may have been covered in the implementation.
